ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [28th February, 2003],

    "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 2003 to 31st March, 2004." - [Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance].

    Question again proposed.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Mr Speaker Sir, the concerns of our people today can be summarised in three words: Jobs, Jobs and Jobs. For working people, they are concerned about keeping their jobs. For retrenched people, they are searching high and low for a job. For young people, they are worried about whether there are vacancies for them after 12 or more years in our rigid and rigorous education system. Furthermore, as the Prime Minister was quoted recently in the papers, the outlook is not getting any better any time soon. The worse is yet to come. As a result, the confidence of Singaporeans about our economy has reached a bottom unprecedented in recent years. Confidence in the PAP leadership's ability to lead us through this downturn, especially amongst those in the category of so-called structural unemployment, is also diminishing.

    On job creation and confidence, the Budget Statement did not take the opportunity to address them in a sufficiently strong and forceful manner to make an

Column: 303

impact. To me, Sir, it is basically a response to the ERC Report issued on 7th February. True, more than 1,000 people, amongst them some of the brightest and the best Singapore has to offer, have contributed their ideas and energies to the deliberations of the ERC Report. However, the gestation period of the Report is one year, which is, indeed, a very long time - one year during which the Government has ample time to formulate responses to some of those recommendations, many of which are not new, as Mr Khaw pointed out to us yesterday.

    For those hoping that this Budget will provide some magic prescriptions to bring us out of the recession, they are disappointed at the lack of any major policy announcements or bold moves. Mr Inderjit Singh expressed this sentiment in his trademark way very well.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the key thread that runs through the ERC Report is the lack of entrepreneurship in Singapore. There are many recommendations to make Singapore society more entrepreneurial. It is important enough for the Government to appoint Mr Raymond Lim to be the Minister-in-charge. Sir, we do not envy Mr Lim in his new job as he has the most unenviable task. How to convert a nation of salary earners to a nation of entrepreneurs? He recognised that our education system is not geared to provide creativity and mentioned that the school system is being changed to cater to this new requirement. Even if we do everything right in the schools, how long would it take us to turn the ship around? How about all those who have left the school system and have already joined the workforce? It is, indeed, a Herculean task. Furthermore, it is not clear what are Mr Lim's powers to make changes and what are his measures of success. Perhaps Mr Lim could find another opportunity to clarify these points.

    However, if we were to depend on new entrepreneurs to help us in the short term, especially in the area of unemployment, our hope would be misguided. The problem is a big one. Let us look at some

Column: 304

numbers. We have close to 80,000 unemployed. If we assume that every new start-up would employ 10 persons, we would need 8,000 new start-ups. Since the success rate of new start-ups is not very high, the number of new enterprises in order to address this problem would have to be in the tens of thousands. From the Registry of Companies' records, we can clearly see that new companies are not being formed fast enough, and we are years away from making a dent in the problem if we were to depend solely on new start-ups.

    Sir, clearly we have to find some alternative means, even if they were the old and outmoded means to address the unemployment situation. Singaporeans are so used to the Government's ability to tackle the problems at hand and to make some policy changes and, presto! - we would be back on the normal growth path within a very short period of time. So much so that we in Government believe that the Government holds the key to job creation and prosperity of our nation. That is also why our people accept the salaries of our Ministers and senior civil servants to be pegged to the private sector. That is why we have the best paid Cabinet in the world. But based on this Budget Statement, there is indeed a mismatch between our people's expectations and the ability of the Government to deliver.

    As usual, Sir, the Feedback Unit conducts dialogue sessions prior to the Budget day. Unlike previous years, participants in our dialogues did not have many new ideas. Perhaps all the new ideas have already been submitted to the ERC. In a fact sheet given to the participants as pre-reading, we asked a question: what would you do if you were the Finance Minister? Perhaps it was a wrong way to prepare the audience. The responses we got could be summarised in this one statement: "If the doctor does not know how to treat the patient, it is time to change the doctor." In short, our people are depending on the Finance Minister to pull rabbits out of the hat. However, on one issue, which I think we have unanimous conclusion, and that is, everyone felt strongly that the Government should not

Column: 305

plan for a budget surplus in this fiscal year. The ground reaction would have been extremely negative had the Minister presented a conservative budget with surpluses. Now that the Budget is a deficit one, people are more relieved. On the other hand, some have pointed out that we could have even a bigger deficit. Mr Leong Horn Kee had brought this up yesterday. But I think we all know that we cannot spend our way out of a recession.

    Perhaps we can ask: why would the Deputy Prime Minister present a budget in this way? This is the first budget he presented after chairing the ERC. Had it been possible, he would probably like to make this Budget Statement a dramatic one. If it had been possible to turn the economy around by one simple Budget Statement, he would have then left an indelible imprint on the population. The bond between the new generation leaders and the younger generation of Singaporeans would then be cemented. Thus, the lack of new measures providing immediate relief in the Budget speaks volumes about the challenges facing us. It should be clear that there are no quick fixes. This should be humbling for the Government to realise that when the tide is against us, even the best Cabinet in the world could not buck the trend. On the other hand, I must give credit to the Deputy Prime Minister for not adopting any quick fix measures that would dig us deeper into the hole, from which we would then have to work harder to climb out of later.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, Government must take charge in leading our people out of the current depression, both with regard to the economy and also the confidence of our people. Government is the only institute we have that is able and could do the task. Mr Khaw has spoken about complacency yesterday. He warned that we would fail as a nation if we were complacent. I would go even further and say that we fail if the Government does not, as a whole, rise to the occasion. However, Singapore has pursued the same formulae of success for so long that perhaps our mindsets and institutions might not be suitable or appropriate to deal with the new challenges facing us.

Column: 306



    In leaving no stone unturned, we could draw some lessons on how successful MNCs react to a changing world. Or rather we can learn more lessons from those outstanding companies that failed to respond to changes. It is true that if we look at the corporate records, some of best companies in the world languish when the market changes. Why? It is not that the management did not foresee the challenges. It is not that the management did not formulate the proper response. They failed because they continued to carry out the counter-measures using the organisational structures and the processes that had worked in the past. They failed because they did not question whether those processes and organisations will continue to work in the new environment. Indeed, some of them went into overdrive, launching programme after programme to check their competitors. I think, as a government, we have to avoid similar pitfalls. We should relook at all Government departments, agencies, both regulatory and promotional ones, to see what needs to be refocused and what needs to be restructured. We should go beyond fashionable name changes such as A*Star, SPRING, and IES - with the result that nowadays people find it difficult to even remember what they stand for. Again, in the spirit of leaving no stone unturned, I suggest that the Government administration, in general, should ask the following questions:

    First, whether strategic frames that have helped us to succeed in the past have become blinders? Such paradigms shape how policymakers view the world and allow us to make quick policy decisions. The same frames can also blind us to emerging threats and opportunities. One example I would like to give here is our land use policy. In the boom time, the Government adopted the policy of assigning a value to every piece of land based on alternative use. Doing so seems logical when such land could be converted to residential use, for instance. But adopting this policy universally means that our infrastructures, such as power generating plants, have to pay high land use fees. Our port authority, the PSA, also has to pay high land use fees. We did not foresee the

Column: 307

emerging threat of Tanjung Pelepas where the operator is given effectively free land by the government. While it would seem that it was the PSA management that lost its two top customers, ultimately, I think, it is still the Government's land use policy that drives up the cost of doing business for PSA. Recognising this, the ERC Report has proposed the concept of competitive factor pricing, which has been accepted in principle by the Government, and we look forward to the detailed implementation of such a policy.

    The second question we should ask is whether proven processes have hardened into routines. We are getting infamous for Government rules and regulations. Mr Raymond Lim had already addressed this and he proposed to time-stamp every rule in the Government. I think also, in this respect, we should ask ourselves whether our Ministries and agencies are fortresses onto themselves. Has the division of labour become so clear that what is undefined is left unattended in the no-man land? For instance, let us ask the question: how could we help the unemployed workers? MOM's response would be coming up with programmes for retraining and upgrading. MTI's response would be looking for more investments. EDB's response would be life sciences. The ERC's response would be to create more entrepreneurs. But who will really help the unemployed to help themselves? I think the question is left unanswered. In the South West CDC, Mayor Yu-Foo has been trying to create a people's market where the unemployed could somehow become self-reliant. But the problems she encountered are indeed monumental.

    The third question we should ask ourselves is whether values, that we have, have hardened into dogmas. It is true that our values inspire and unify our people. However, they too can harden into rigid, self-defeating policies. For instance, the HDB's housing policy provides two bites of the cherry for every Singapore citizen. However, by pursuing it without putting on our thinking hat, the Government is today left with a backlog of thousands of

Column: 308

unsold flats. This brought the building programme of HDB to a halt. The building contractors that have been dependent on HDB's building programme are all now facing difficulties, some are facing bankruptcy. The other example is the CPF contribution rates. On the one hand, we say that CPF should return to the basics of providing for retirement. On the other hand, we somehow convince ourselves that the proper CPF total contribution rate is 40%. So, when the economy turns around, we pledge that we should restore that number to 40%. Mr Inderjit Singh pointed out yesterday that such a policy creates uncertainties with regard to the cost of doing business in Singapore.

    It is not only the promotional agencies, such as EDB, JTC, IES and STB, that should subject themselves to this particular review by asking themselves the three questions I have proposed. I have also in mind regulatory agencies, such as Immigration, Fire Department, URA, etc. In fact, one of my favourite gripes is the hurdle imposed by immigration on visitors from emerging countries, like India and China. It might have been true that, in the past, many visitors from these countries ended up as over-stayers. But to treat every applicant from these countries who visits Singapore as a potential over-stayer would indeed deprive many business opportunities for tourism and education enterprises in Singapore.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, many of the changes that we propose will involve pain. When the Government promises that no stone will be left unturned, no one expected that the Government will respond to some of the worms under those stones by restructuring the Government agencies, such as PSA and HDB, through massive retrenchment or early unemployment. While shedding surplus manpower is oftentimes the right approach, making jobs redundant, in particular by the Government, should be the last resort.

    Sir, a job is more than just a person receiving a pay cheque. A job indeed defines the role of the person in society. It gives the person respect and dignity. Often times, the workers are not at fault.

Column: 309

Again, let us come back to the case of PSA. It is the management that lost the top two customers through inflexibility or insensitivity. However, if you look further, as I said earlier, it is also the Government land use policy that saddles PSA with a burdensome land cost that PSA must recover from its customers. Thus, the Government is ultimately responsible for PSA's troubles. Extending this idea to all businesses, it is also clear that Government land use policy has played a major role in bringing us to our current difficulties. Only the Government could unwind the situation that we found ourselves in.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, notwithstanding my comments, I found the Budget indeed to be a very carefully crafted one, balancing the short term needs as well as the long term goals of our country. It is a deficit budget designed to maintain Government expenditure in a shrinking economy. It maintains the support for the lower income groups. And furthermore, the Deputy Prime Minister has been bold to introduce several new measures, such as tax exemption for foreign-sourced income and interest on local bank deposits. The first exemption has been proposed repeatedly in the past by Feedback Unit participants. I am indeed very glad that the Government has finally agreed to this suggestion. The tax exemption on interest on local bank deposits is indeed quite unexpected. It is indeed quite uncommon in this world to find a government that is prepared to exempt taxes on interest from savings account. I believe this exemption will continue to promote the habit of saving and will provide great relief to our retirees who are largely dependent on their savings to see them through retirement. I would like to thank the Minister on their behalf.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the prescription of the Minister for our economy reminds me of the approach between western medicine and herbal medicine. Western medicine provides quick and effective relief but sometimes has severe side effects. On the other hand, herbal medicine must be taken over a long time. It is also a more holistic approach that probably would bring about better long term health.

Column: 310

Singaporeans have been expecting western medicine in this Budget, but the Minister has prescribed herbal medicine. It would have been ideal if the Minister could prescribe a blend of western and herbal medicines so that we would have the best of both worlds from both practices.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, our economy is indeed in transition. As Mr Raymond Lim pointed out, in a knowledge era, those resource-endowed countries are not necessarily those that would emerge as winners. Often times, the resource-deprived countries are those that would vault ahead of the others. In this respect, I am reminded of the analogy of the evolution of species. Species evolved from a small population are subject to rapid and severe change in the environment. The weaker ones are eliminated and only those who can adapt would survive. Our economy is now subject to severe challenges. Elimination of the weaker companies is painful but necessary. Sir, I believe that so long as we take care to maintain social cohesion through helping those unfortunate amongst us, Singapore will emerge stronger and fitter at the end of this journey. I thank the Minister for a thoughtful Budget that strikes a balance between the diverse needs of the economy.

    I support the motion standing in his name.

    Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I be allowed to make a clarification on what I said yesterday in respect of the cost of the bypass operation?

    Mr Speaker: Provided it is a clarification and no debate. You have to be concise.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: It will be a short one.

    Mr Speaker: OK, go ahead.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: May I clarify my speech on the point about the two brothers who went for bypass operations. The one done in Singapore at Mount Elizabeth cost him almost S$30,000, and

Column: 311

not S$40,000, as I said yesterday. The other operation done in Malaysia at Johor Baru General Hospital cost him Malaysian Ringgit 500, or S$235 if we take the exchange rate at S0.47 cents to M$1. Both operations were done in 1998.

    Sir, I have checked with NUH this morning that, for a C class patient in NUH who has undergone a bypass, the estimated cost is about S$3,500 and the stay is about seven days. So even if we compare hospital with hospital, Singapore's cost is more than ten times that of Malaysia.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Finance Minister labelled this year's Budget as "Seizing Opportunity in Uncertainty". The headline caption in the Lianhe Zaobao described it as "Relieving current concerns to build long-term advantage". But, to the general public, this is a budget that cares not for the predicament of the people and offers no help to them at all.

    To the ordinary people, the utilities, SC&CC rebates are merely some meagre favours. At the time when the economic growth was good, and the Government accumulated huge surpluses, they gave just a little in terms of rebates, and glorified them by declaring that the Government was sharing the wealth with the people. Today, with an unemployment rate as high as 4.5%, and still mounting continuously, the rebates remain the same. Take the utilities rebate as an example. In the 1996 Budget, the utilities rebate amounted to $73 million. This year, with a situation where retrenchments are escalating, and those who are lucky enough to keep their jobs get no bonus and even suffer a pay cut, the rebates package is $71 million. Not only has it not been increased, it is actually reduced.

    The Prime Minister said that the present economic difficulty has not bottomed out yet and that we must be prepared for the worst to come. In his Budget Statement, the Finance Minister urged our people to help one another and put in concerted

Column: 312

efforts to pull through the difficult times. But having said that, does the Minister lead by extending his nimble and agile hand to prevent those who were falling from dropping into the water, or pull out those who are already in the water and drowning? Absolutely NO, the Minister is merely stretching his fingers at his original position. These utilities rebates and SC&CC exemption cannot effectively relieve the anxiety. As it was said by an economist, the short-term rebates are indeed lacking in bearing.

    Perhaps the Minister for Finance may say proudly that he had issued to our people the Economic Restructuring Shares, and two-thirds of the shareholders have already cashed out their shares. But we must not forget that the ERS are only given as a sugar coating over the poison of increasing the GST. With higher GST, we have to pay more tax each day, be it at the wet markets, supermarkets, hospitals or on the road. . Three years down the road, I am sure that there would not be any more ERS to be issued. Will the Minister for Finance lift the GST then? Surely not! We may even expect a heavier GST.

    The Finance Minister may say that one cannot make bricks without straw. There is no growth in our economy, the Government's revenue is reduced. All that can be done has already been done. But I am sure the hand of the Finance Minister is certainly more nimble and agile than those of the families where the breadwinners have lost their jobs, and those who are struggling for survival. The PAP Ministers are well known for their ability to create wealth and preparing for the rainy days. Now that the rain has come, if the Finance Minister is sympathetic to the people on their present predicament, surely he can bring the initiative of his wisdom and creativity into full play and do more for the people.

    The Prime Minister said that he was afraid that the Government's various rebates given to help the people lighten their financial burden may be habitually taken for granted by the people. The people's dependency on the Government

Column: 313

not only causes him to be worried, but also to feel that it is dangerous. He sincerely and earnestly urged the people to move away from the dependency mentality, and make every attempt to resolve their own problems. However, I wish to remind the Government that when we see a 80-year-old granny bending her fragile body to glean and collect scraps from the rubbish heap, when we see a university graduate putting aside his academic excellence to roast chestnuts for sale, when we see a youngster concealing his MA qualification to apply for a job as a warehouse assistant, we know that most Singaporeans want to live with dignity. They will certainly seek to be self-reliant.

    The PAP Government should not use the conduct of a small group of Singaporeans as a criterion, and use the excuse of not wanting the people to degenerate and forget about the promises they made during the last General Election. Do not forget that the Prime Minister has also said that the people's problems are his problems and their concerns are his concerns too. The Prime Minister is going to retire to give way to a younger person soon. I hope that the Minister for Finance who is going to succeed him as Prime Minister will remember what he said.

    Faced with the threat of retrenchment, pay cut, zero bonus, uncertain economic prospect, I feel that it is even more important that the Government should give the people a clear signal, to let the people know that the Government is resolute in wanting to lower their cost of living. Today, the burden on the people's shoulders is so heavy that they could hardly breathe. According to a recent report by Goldman Sachs, the debt-to-income ratio of an average Singaporean family is the highest in the world. Singaporeans consider owning their own residential property as their first priority. With 93% of the families owning their own home, every family is in debt. With the series of impacts since 1996, the debt-to-income ratio of an average Singaporean family has risen from 122% to 174%.

    Faced with a whole series of retrenchment exercises, uncertainty in job security

Column: 314

coupled with the heavy debts, the people's worry is indeed understandable.

    For all these years, I have been repeatedly asking the Government to carefully review its policy on public service charges. Even in the good years, we should not use market forces as a cover, raising the standard of services as an excuse, and affordability of the people as the logic to keep on raising public service charges. The Government should have exercised control over the cost of living, give people a chance to catch their breath, and keep the wealth with the people. HDB flat pricing is a good example. It causes people to be up to their ears in debt. But the Government turned a deaf ear to all these appeals. Even in current bad times, on the excuse of raising the standard of service, public transport charges, medical fees and all sorts of charges such as taxi licence fees, etc, have been adjusted upwards.

    Apparently, the People's Action Party Government will never commit to freeze charges over a long period of time, this will cut off its sources of revenue. Once the economy recovers, the Government will go back to its old tricks of using free-market policy as a cover to increase its charges. Did the Finance Minister not point out in his Budget Statement that in good times, the Government will accumulate surpluses to offset the deficits. Increasing public service charges has been a significant means for the Government to accumulate surpluses. The only difference from now onwards is that business cost cannot be increased by a large margin for fear of frightening away the foreign investors and with such constraints, the PAP Government will surely turn to the people for their revenue, like increasing GST. Furthermore, in order to maintain its competitiveness, the Government will also control tightly the wage level of the people. Under such circumstances, the predicament of the people is clearly imaginable.

    As such, I would like to, once again, appeal to the Government to take the high cost of living of our people seriously and to change the policy and principle of

Column: 315

public service charges, reconvene the Cost Review Committee to identify the problems, prescribe the correct medicine, and relieve the real concerns of the people, rather than distributing shares before the General Election, and then increasing the various fees and charges after the General Election.

    The Minister for Finance repeatedly emphasised that the main aim and strategy of this budget is to create opportunities for enhancing productivity and increasing job opportunities. Can I ask the Minister how many people have lost their jobs since the last General Election, and how many job opportunities have the Government created? Among these newly created job opportunities, how many are taken up by foreign talents because Singaporeans are not competent enough to take them on? The Government says that there are plenty of vacancies in our labour market, but Singaporeans are not prepared to lower their expectations to take on these jobs. Has the Government made any attempt to find out why there is such an anomaly?

    Dr Jennifer Lee (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, I would like to draw attention to two big areas of concern for Singapore, both of which relate to our demographics - our aging population and our declining fertility.

As the latter group is largely women, who will in all probability outlive their husbands, their financial security in old age will be precarious.

    The ERC has taken the approach in its recommendations that CPF should cater for the 10th to the 80th percentile of the income spectrum. Now, this approach makes eminent sense, as indeed the top 20% can very well look after itself and, truly, the bottom 10% would have so little put aside through regular contribution rates - as well as did every dollar that they earned to meet their immediate day-to-day expenditures - that it does not

Column: 390

make sense to have them make an employee contribution at all.

Given this scenario of the lack of any savings at all for the bottom 10%, the full-time home-makers not catered for in the CPF system, the anticipated inability of 40% of CPF account holders in the future to meet the Minimum Sum target, and indeed the likely inadequacy of that sum to generate enough monthly income to maintain a desired living standard, it seems to me that a critical part of the solution must be the continued employability and employment of older workers.

    Many of us must be looking to being employed well beyond our current expectations, not only to keep active and engaged, but also to generate some

Column: 391

continuing income to supplement what we have been able to put aside as savings. Column: 394

scheme will have to be worked out to prevent gaming and abuse.

Column: 396

foreign patients paying full rates help hospitals in operating costs and may moderate the need for future hospital fees hikes.

healthcare at private facilities to help generate economies of scale in the private sector and enable them to provide more cost-competitive services.
